DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Says No Major Withdrawal from Pacific Bases Planned
DOC.TEXT: Pentagon officials said Wednesday they were not actively considering a major military withdrawal from East Asia, although planners recently drafted a memorandum outlining such a possibility. The Asahi Shimbun and Washington Post reported this week that Pentagon officials were considering closing U.S. bases in the Philippines and withdrawing forces from South Korea and Japan. That policy was outlined in a paper discussed at a meeting Monday involving Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, but many other options also were discussed, said two Pentagon officials. ``There is no decision and no deadline for a decision,'' said one of the sources. Both officials spoke on the condition he not be further identified. Another source said that no such withdrawal was being considered for the next two or three years. ``Our security in the Pacific is based on a robust presence, based on agreements with as many nations as possible,'' and therefore the United States is unlikely to close any East Asian bases in the near future, said another official. The meeting among the top Pentagon brass concerned ``the future of U.S. security interests in the Pacific. We are looking at a number of long-term possibilities,'' said one source. Consideration of reducing the U.S. military presence in the Pacific was prompted by changes in Eastern Europe and budgetary restraints. ``There has been a change'' in the Soviet Bloc. ``The threat is reduced,'' said the source. U.S. Pacific forces include 222,238 personnel _ 50,000 in Japan, 45,000 in Hawaii, 32,000 in South Korea, and 34,000 at sea, according to Pentagon statistics. Additionally, the United States operates two important bases in the Philippines.
